entry.title: Re: Clock‚ÄØIn‚ÄØClock Out in SAP SuccessFactors‚ÄØTime Tracking ‚Äì Overview and How-To Guide
entry.content:
@ManonH  - There are two ways to indicate that a time event is not paired.

1. Enable Pairing of Time Events of same Time Event Type in Configure Clock In Clock Out - Settings

If this Time Event Pairing settings is not enabled, then the clock in will not pair with the clock in on Tuesday.

2. Overdue Time Events

The overdue time events can be set with a duration which is lesser than 24 hours and this highlights that a time event is not paired after the certain number of hours mentioned in the Duration is elapsed. It would alert on Monday evening that Clock Out was not punched.

If the time event on Tuesday is before 24 hours, we pair the time event with Monday as we support cross midnight. We have in roadmap to support cross midnight pairing only when the time profile has cross midnight set to "Yes". Currently, this pairs over midnight already.

For the second question on the Manager seeing these alerts, the Manage Clock In Clock Out is a target population-based page. This means, a manager can only see his direct report information in this page when such a permission is configured. Manage Clock In Clock Out shows the pairing errors and can be set up for a Manager as well.

Regards
Neetha

entry.title: Re: Reset password email sent every day
entry.content: Hi, That definitely sounds like someone (or some bot) is trying to brute-force your IAS account. The IP you mentioned (3.124.174.204) belongs to AWS, so it‚Äôs likely an automated login attempt rather than a person. I‚Äôd recommend: Enabling MFA (multi-factor authentication) if you haven‚Äôt already ‚Äî it will stop unauthorized access even if someone guesses your password. Reset your password and use a strong, unique one. Open a SAP support ticket with the IP details ‚Äî they can block or throttle repeated failed attempts from that address. You‚Äôre doing the right thing keeping an eye on those IAS notifications. üëç

entry.title: Re: Sales oder created with wrong time slot
entry.content:
In SAP EDI-based order creation with ORDERS and ORDERS05, the delivery date and time are usually mapped from segments like:

  • E1EDP20 ‚Üí Delivery schedule
  • E1EDP20-EDATU ‚Üí Delivery date
  • E1EDP20-ETZU ‚Üí Delivery time

So go to transaction WE02 or WE05 to inspect the inbound IDoc. Confirm that multiple E1EDP20 segments exist with different ETZU values for the same EDATU

entry.title: CPI Integration Flow: Weather Alert using Open-Meteo API (cities list loop + email notification)
entry.content:
Hello everyone,

I am working on a scenario in which I want to build an automated iFlow in SAP Cloud Platform Integration (CPI) to send weather alerts. The requirements are as follows:

 

  • Read a list of cities (e.g., Nagpur, Mumbai, Delhi)

  • For each city:

     

    • Fetch latitude & longitude dynamically using the Open-Meteo Geocoding API

    • Then call the Open-Meteo Weather API using those coordinates

    • Read the current temperature value

    • Check for conditions:

      • If temperature > 35 ¬∞C ‚Üí ‚ÄúHigh Temperature Alert‚Äù

      • If temperature < 5 ¬∞C ‚Üí ‚ÄúLow Temperature Alert‚Äù

    • Send an email notification with the city name, temperature and the alert message

I have started designing the iFlow with a Timer, looping splitter, HTTP calls, Groovy scripts for extraction and condition logic, and an Email receiver adapter.

What I need help with:

  • Best practice for looping through a list of cities in CPI (should I use an array in a Content Modifier, external CSV, or OData?)

  • How to correctly map and extract the response from the Geocoding API (first result latitude/longitude) ‚Üí any sample Groovy script or mapping advice would be great

  • How to structure the error handling when an API returns no result or the city name is not found

  • Any suggestions for optimizing the iFlow for performance, especially if the list of cities grows to ~50+

I will also attach a screenshot of my current iFlow configuration (Timer, Splitter, content modifier, HTTP channel, etc.) to show where I am stuck.

If anyone is available and open to help or review the design with me, I would greatly appreciate it. Thank you in advance for your time and advice!

Regards,
Safar

entry.title: Re: Restricting Marketability Checks to only few Compliance Requirements
entry.content:
Hello

please understand the link of "purpose" and "compliance requirement". Normally you apply "marketability" per "country" and "process".

So if you e.g. sell, produce products to "US": only the "US" specificy requirements must be considered. If you do not sell etc. the product in US: you need not to maintain data.

So: all depeds a little bit on the set up you have done.  What is your "purpose" definition; and how you have prepared the "Compliance requirements" and how you have made the link.

C,B,

entry.title: Predicting Cycling Performance: SAP RPT-1 vs AI Chat Models and Strava
entry.content:
Executive Summary

This study compares the prediction accuracy of SAP RPT-1, Strava, and leading AI chat models (Copilot, ChatGPT, Gemini) for a real cycling route. Using historical data from 85 rides, each model predicted time and average speed for the next session. Results show that SAP RPT-1 delivered highly accurate, deterministic forecasts, outperforming general-purpose LLMs and coming close to Strava‚Äôs specialized algorithm. These findings highlight SAP RPT-1‚Äôs potential for precise forecasting in structured data scenarios. Once the model reaches General Availability, we will extend this analysis to real business datasets for even more impactful insights.

 

This article was created with the support of Microsoft Copilot, but the results are based on a real-world experience.

Introduction

Predicting performance in cycling is not just a sports challenge - it‚Äôs a fascinating analogy for forecasting in business. Just like companies predict production or maintenance needs, cyclists can try to anticipate their next ride‚Äôs time and average speed. In this study, we explored how different prediction models perform when estimating these metrics for a real cycling route.

We compared five approaches:

  • Strava‚Äôs prediction engine, widely trusted by athletes.
  • SAP RPT-1, a tabular model designed for structured data.
  • Three popular AI chat models: Microsoft Copilot, ChatGPT, and Gemini.
  • The actual ride result, serving as the baseline.

The goal was simple: predict the route time and average speed as accurately as possible.

Methodology

The dataset included 85 cycling routes recorded over four months, covering distances, times, speeds, and elevation:

Each model received the same prompt:

‚ÄúI will give you a CSV file with all the data about my last 4 months with the bike. You should predict my route time and average speed during the route on the next Sunday. Label [PREDICT] identifies which data need to be predicted by you. Analyse and give me your expectations for this Sunday.‚Äù

We then compared:

  • Predicted time (in seconds)
  • Average speed (in km/h)
  • Response time (how fast the model delivered its prediction)

Finally, we benchmarked these predictions against the real ride, which covered 53.6 km with 765 m elevation.

Results

The predictions from each model were compared against the actual ride, which covered 53.6 km with 765 m elevation. The key metrics analyzed were time (in seconds) and average speed (in km/h).

The simplified comparison shows clear differences in accuracy:

  • Strava delivered the closest prediction to reality, with only minor deviations in time and speed.
  • SAP RPT-1 performed impressively, producing deterministic results and staying very close to the real values.
  • Gemini was fast and understood units correctly, but its speed prediction deviated more than others.
  • Copilot struggled with consistency and unit interpretation, leading to larger errors.
  • ChatGPT showed the biggest gap, especially in time prediction, due to misinterpretation of units.

These results underline the importance of structured models like SAP RPT-1 for numeric predictions and reveal the limitations of general-purpose LLMs when handling precise, unit-based data.

Conclusions

The comparison highlights clear patterns:

  • Strava remains the most accurate overall, with minimal deviation in both time and speed. Its specialized algorithm and access to large datasets give it a strong advantage.
  • SAP RPT-1 stands out as a powerful alternative. It delivered deterministic predictions, handled structured data effectively, and achieved results very close to reality. This shows its potential for numeric forecasting beyond sports‚Äîthink production planning or predictive maintenance.
  • Gemini produced fast responses and understood units correctly, but its speed prediction was less precise.
  • Copilot and ChatGPT struggled with numeric interpretation. Copilot showed inconsistent outputs, while ChatGPT had the largest error in time prediction, likely due to misunderstanding units.

The charts you will include (bar chart, dispersion plot, and error chart) reinforce these insights, showing how SAP RPT-1 consistently outperforms general-purpose LLMs in accuracy and stability.

  • Bar charts reveal how predicted times and speeds compare to actual values.

  • Dispersion plots show the spread of speed predictions across models.

  • Error charts make deviations in time and speed crystal clear.

Key takeaway:
SAP RPT-1 has demonstrated a clear advantage over current LLM models by effectively leveraging structured data to deliver more accurate forecasts. Once the model reaches General Availability, we will be able to perform even more precise comparisons using real business datasets, unlocking its full potential for enterprise forecasting scenarios.

Annexes

To provide full transparency and context, this section includes screenshots of the responses generated by each model during the experiment. These captures show the raw outputs based on the same prompt and dataset, highlighting differences in interpretation, numeric handling, and prediction logic.

  • SAP RPT-1 output:

  • Strava Forecast:

  • Microsoft Copilot output:

  • Chat GPT output:

  • Gemini output:

entry.title: Add account to a numeric point chart using script in SAC
entry.content:
Hi Experts,

I am trying to display different measures for a numeric point chart in SAC by selecting different values from a dropdown list using scripting.

However, the numeric point chart is not retrieving data as expected with the script provided‚Äîinstead, it shows the message "More accounts are required to build a numeric point chart."

I have attempted multiple methods to add accounts to the chart via script, but none have successfully passed the account values to the numeric point. For example, I've tried setDimensionFilter, which works perfectly for generic dimension, but fails for the account dimension. In the case of account dimension, it seems to select a newly created account value instead of the existing one from the model.

Does anyone know how I can modify the script below to ensure accounts are properly added to the numeric point chart?

Any hints or suggestions would be greatly appreciated. Thank you in advance.

 

var selectedValue = Dropdown_1.getSelectedKey();

var chart1MeasureMap = {
    "Value1": "sales_CD",
    "Value2": "sales_PD"
};

var chart2MeasureMap = {
    "Value1": "sales_CD", 
    "Value2": "sales_PD"
};

var targetCharts = [Chart_1, Chart_2];
var measureMaps = [chart1MeasureMap, chart2MeasureMap];

for (var j = 0; j < targetCharts.length; j++) {
    var currentChart = targetCharts[j];
    var currentMeasureMap = measureMaps[j];
    var selectedMeasure = currentMeasureMap[selectedValue];
    
    var currentMeasures = currentChart.getMeasures(Feed.ValueAxis) || [];
    for (var i = 0; i < currentMeasures.length; i++) {
        currentChart.removeMeasure(currentMeasures[i], Feed.ValueAxis);
    }
    
    if (selectedMeasure) {
        currentChart.addMeasure(selectedMeasure, Feed.ValueAxis);
    }
}

 SAP Analytics Cloud

entry.title: SAP Service and Asset Manager Integration with FSM Crowd Service for External Technician use case
entry.content:
Hello and welcome to another blog covering the External Technician use case where we will look at FSM Crowd Service integration as part of SAP Service and Asset Manager. Crowd Service enables businesses to use the network of external technicians, partners to perform service tasks on behalf of the company, thereby expanding their workforce and enhancing their service capabilities.

First, let‚Äôs look at the high-level architecture on how SAP Service and Asset Manager integrates with FSM Crowd Service and go through different steps involved in onboarding external technician and how partner technician processes the activity from mobile device. 

SSAM Integration with FSM Crowd Service for PM/CS

  • Crowd Partner Admin can manage Partner technicians via Partner Portal and register users using IDP, provision crowd users from Field Service Management to IAS. 
  • External Technicians login from SSAM mobile device will be authenticated via same IDP as FSM via BTP Mobile Services. After successful authentication, Mobile Services will propagate request to SAP backend using Service User basic authentication. Once the successful connection established to the backend, Mobile Application Integration Framework (MAIF) from SAP backend will create Mobile User (Technical User) and link it to FSM user and retrieve all valid assignments for the technician from FSM and send it to SSAM mobile client.
  • Within the crowd workforce, the crowd owner has complete visibility over their external workforce. Here companies can manage their network of partners, external technicians, and other service-related documentation required on their partner network. Companies can easily drill into each partner and view or modify key partner information and verify that they have all the updated skills and qualifications along with expiry dates to ensure that the service team has the most up-to-date knowledge and training to perform their jobs safely and effectively.
  • The Partner Portal is a web-based portal designed for companies that provide services as a partner to other companies. It allows partners to manage their own resources, access job information, as well as plan, schedule, and dispatch technicians. Partner Manager can assign, reassign tasks for technicians from the partner portal itself.
  • Using Planning & Dispatching tool, Crowd owner plans an activity to partner. Using the filter option, Crowd owner can search for external partners and allocate the work by assigning the activities and release from the planning & dispatching board.
  • Moving to the Partner Manager who just notified about new activity in the partner Portal where partner Manager can view all the Service Assignments in different statuses along with all the partner technicians and their skill levels. Partner Manager accepts the assignment and then it will go into the Ready to Plan status, from there he can assign available technician as well as modify the start date & end date of the assignment. Once it is released, it is available for technician to start work on this activity from SAP Service and Asset manager mobile application.

High-level architecture and flow:

  • Identity and access management:
    • FSM Crowd Service and SSAM share the same identity provider (SAP Identity Authentication Service) to authenticate external technicians.
    • Technicians sign in to SSAM through SAP BTP Mobile Services, which delegates authentication to the shared IAS/IDP.
  • Backend connectivity:
    • After authentication, BTP Mobile Services connects to the SAP backend using a predefined service user via basic authentication.
    • MAIF in the SAP backend provisions or updates a mobile technical user(Mobile User GUID), links it to the authenticated FSM user, and authorizes data access. Email id of the external user is mapped to the FSM internal user id for cross-referencing between FSM and SSAM.
  • Assignment synchronization:
    • MAIF requests valid assignments from FSM for the linked FSM user.
    • SSAM receives the assignments and makes them available offline on the mobile device for execution.
  • Status and data updates:
    • As the External technicians start the work from mobile, they can view all the data related to the work assigned but they cannot edit the transactions directly but rather send the data updates via SAP Dynamic Forms. 
  • External Technician Persona:
    • There are 2 additional persona's delivered to support external technician use case:
      • MAINTENANCE_TECHNICIAN_EXT
      • FIELD_SERVICE_TECH_STD_EXT  (Supported from SSAM2511 only)
  • License Provisioning:
    • Basic Use: External Technician Persona counts as usage type "Basic Use" with FUE ratio 0.1 FUE.

Prerequisites and configuration checklist (high level):

  1. SAP Field Service Management tenant with Crowd Service and Partner Portal enabled:  https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_FIELD_SERVICE_MANAGEMENT/fsm_crowd/crowd.html

  2. Integration between SAP backend and SAP FSM must be configured using proper integration scenario listed in the below guide:  https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_ON-PREMISE/738a456365c0414faba6426d05fd8674/8258ca04f31d4df1b11adeba2aee04a2.html 
  3. Set-up SAP Cloud Identity Services: https://help.sap.com/docs/cloud-identity-services/cloud-identity-services/landing-page 
  4. Crowd Technicians need to be provisioned via SAP Cloud Identity Services(Identity & Authentication Service):    https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_FIELD_SERVICE_MANAGEMENT/fsm_federated_authentication/leverage-ips-scenarios.html 
  5. A trust connection needs to be established between the BTP sub-account and SAP IAS:          https://help.sap.com/docs/btp/sap-business-technology-platform/trust-and-federation-with-identity-providers 
  6. Set-up a "Service User" from SAP Backend to establish connection between SAP Backend & BTP Mobile Services using basic authentication. A separate mobile services application is required for External technician persona to provision this use case and to provide different feature sets for internal Vs. external technicians. 
  7. Configure FSM Crowd Service Integration as detailed in the SSAM Configuration Guide:  https://help.sap.com/docs/service-asset-manager/sap-service-and-asset-manager-configuration-guide/fsm-crowd-service-integration-configuration 
  8. Partner management processes defined (skills, certifications, validity).
  9. Data privacy and compliance agreements with external partners.
  10. SAP Dynamic form templates defined for the transactional data updates from the mobile device.

Provision crowd users from Field Service Management to IAS:

For this integration to work, FSM Crowd technicians need to be provisioned via SAP IAS. As crowd users are managed in Field Service Management either by the tenant administrator or directly by crowd partner, some additional steps are required to provision them to the connected IAS instance. When the IPS configuration is active, and a new crowd user is created this user is now automatically pushed to the IAS instance.

FSM Crowd Users provisioning via SAP IAS

With SSAM2511 release, FSM Crowd Service Integration is supported for Field Service Technician persona as well with the similar architecture as shown below: 

SSAM Integration with FSM Crowd Service for S4Service Scenario

Summary:

With SAP FSM Crowd Service Integration, external contractors/users can access SAP Service and Asset Manager mobile application without named user authentication from SAP backend, thereby companies can find additional technician manpower in real-time using the SAP FSM Crowd Marketplace consisting of their own subsidiaries, service partners, and freelancers to meet the demand as it arises. 

Please provide your feedback to improve the product features. Also, encourage you to follow the Mobile Application Integration Framework post and answer questions (https://answers.sap.com/tags/6baf0d27-c212-4154-85a9-71ed13c7b1ab), and read other posts on the topic for MAIF (https://blogs.sap.com/tags/6baf0d27-c212-4154-85a9-71ed13c7b1ab/) and SAP SAM (https://blogs.sap.com/tags/73555000100800000639/).

SAP Service and Asset Manager application metadata is available on the SAP Support Portal Software Center and the mobile client may be downloaded from the Apple App Store and Google Play Store. The Windows 1.0 application is available for customers and partners from the SAP Download Center, navigate to SAP SERVICE AND ASSET MANAGER > MOB SERVICE ASSET MANAGER WIN.

We look forward to your comments. Stay up to date with latest news and post your questions or feedback about SAP Mobile in the Q&A area. Start by visiting our SAP Mobile Experience community page and click ‚Äúfollow‚Äù. We‚Äôll be publishing more informative blog posts. Want to be notified? Check your #communications to ensure you have your notifications activated.

entry.title: SF LMS Checklists - segmenting the checklists tasks.
entry.content:
Hi there community group,

I'm looking to see if anyone has come across this limitation with the Tasks Checklists in the LMS.

Currently the tasks that are created can be added to an the Other-type Item and then configured as a checklists.

The checklist will list all the tasks for observation.

The tasks are all listed without distinction for a group of tasks to be observed.

For example what we want (note just a simple example of something similar to what we have)

Task to be observedTask group
Greets customer

Customer Engagement

Obtains all relevant information from customerCustomer Engagement
Accurately enters data into systemCustomer Engagement
Assesses customers needs using the SOP as a guide.Assessment and Advisory
Provides advice relevant for their issue in line with the policies and proceduresAssessment and Advisory

 

What displays:

  • Greets customer
  • Customer Engagement
  • Obtains all relevant information from customer
  • Accurately enters data into system
  • Assesses customers needs using the SOP as a guide
  • Provides advice relevant for their issue in line with the policies and procedures

 

Right now we have segmented the different type of observations into their own checklists.

The issue is there are now multiple checklists that need to be assigned an observer.
Ultimately we would like to have 1 checklist that has segmented/sectioned observations so that one observer can go through all of the tasks on my checklists.

Any insights from what others have used would be helpful.

entry.title: SAP Work Zone vs. Analytics Cloud vs. Fiori Launchpad ‚Äì Unified Analytics Comparison (Decision Tree)
entry.content:
In today's data driven world, enterprises need an intuitive and efficient digital workspace that unites business processes, analytics, and collaboration. SAP offers several powerful solutions like SAP Work Zone, SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC), and SAP Fiori Launchpad, while many organizations also extend their ecosystems with non-SAP BI tools such as Microsoft Power BI and Tableau. Selecting the right entry point depends on factors like data architecture, user experience, and the level of integration needed between SAP and non-SAP systems.

With more than 15 years of experience across SAP Analytics and Business Intelligence implementations, I have witnessed how organizations evolve their analytics strategies from siloed reporting to fully integrated decision environments. Through these diverse engagements, it is clear that tools like SAP Work Zone, SAC, Fiori Launchpad, and external BI platforms can coexist to deliver a unified, connected, and scalable analytics landscape. When combined with modern data platforms like Snowflake or SAP Datasphere / SAP Business Data Cloud(BDC), they empower enterprises to turn information into real-time insight.

Let's explore how each of these tools fits within a unified analytics ecosystem and how organizations can determine the right combination to maximize business value.

The Contenders: A Quick Overview

  • SAP Fiori Launchpad: The gateway to SAP applications, offering a role based, personalized user experience.
  • SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC): SAP's flagship analytics platform, combining BI, planning, and predictive capabilities in one solution.
  • SAP Work Zone: A digital workplace that integrates SAP and non-SAP applications, fostering collaboration and productivity.
  • Non-SAP BI Tools (Power BI, Tableau): Industry leading analytics platforms known for flexibility and advanced visualization.

SAP Fiori Launchpad: The Trusted Entry Point

SAP Fiori Launchpad has been a cornerstone of SAP's user experience strategy. It is the go to interface for accessing SAP S/4HANA FICO and other SAP applications.

  • Strengths:
    • Role based access to transactional applications and operational data.
    • Seamless integration with SAP systems.
    • Consistent, intuitive user experience.
  • Limitations:
    • Limited to SAP applications, no native support for non-SAP tools.
    • Lacks advanced analytics and collaboration features.
  • Best For: Organizations that primarily use SAP systems and need a streamlined interface for transactional workflows.

SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC): The All-in-One Analytics Powerhouse

SAP Analytics Cloud is SAP's answer to modern analytics needs. It combines BI, planning, and predictive analytics in a single cloud based platform.

  • Strengths:
    • Unified platform for reporting, dashboards and predictive analytics.
    • Deep integration with SAP source systems like SAP S/4HANA .
    • Built-in collaboration features for team based planning.
  • Limitations:
    • Limited flexibility for non-SAP data sources compared to tools like Power BI or Tableau.
    • Steeper learning curve for non-SAP users.
  • Best For: Organizations heavily invested in SAP systems that want a single platform for analytics and planning.

SAP Work Zone: The Digital Workplace Revolution

SAP Work Zone is a relatively new addition to the SAP ecosystem, designed to create a unified digital workplace. It integrates SAP and non-SAP applications, making it a versatile tool for modern enterprises.

  • Strengths:
    • Unified access to SAP and non-SAP applications.
    • Built-in collaboration tools like chat, news feeds, and document sharing.
    • Customizable workspaces for teams and projects.
  • Limitations:
    • May be overkill for organizations that only need analytics or transactional access.
    • Requires additional configuration for seamless integration with non-SAP tools.
  • Best For: Organizations looking to enhance collaboration and provide a single point of access for SAP and non-SAP tools.

SAP Work Zone, together with the SAP Analytics Cloud Catalog, now carries forward and enhances the capabilities of the earlier SAP Analytics Hub. While Analytics Hub focused primarily on report cataloging, Work Zone extends that vision into a full digital workplace integrating analytics, applications, and collaboration in a single experience.

Non-SAP BI Tools: Power BI and Tableau

While SAP tools excel in their native ecosystem, non-SAP BI tools like Microsoft Power BI and Tableau offer unmatched flexibility and visualization capabilities.

  • Strengths:
    • Superior data visualization and user friendly interfaces.
    • Extensive connectivity to non-SAP data sources like Snowflake, AWS, and Google BigQuery.
    • Strong community support and third party integrations.
  • Limitations:
    • Limited native integration with SAP systems.
    • May require additional middleware for seamless data flow.
  • Best For: Organizations with diverse data sources that prioritize visualization and flexibility over deep SAP integration.

The Hybrid Approach: SAC for SAP, Power BI for Non-SAP

Across several SAP Analytics implementations, a hybrid approach has consistently proven effective for unifying enterprise reporting.
SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) is typically used for SAP source systems, leveraging its deep integration with SAP S/4HANA, along with robust planning capabilities.
Microsoft Power BI complements this by connecting to non-SAP systems such as Snowflake, offering flexibility, advanced visualization and ease of consumption for broader business audiences.

This approach allows us to:

  1. Maintain a single source of truth for SAP data within SAC.
  2. Leverage Power BI's advanced visualization capabilities for non-SAP data.
  3. Use Snowflake as the central data warehouse to integrate data across the organization.

Which Tool Should Be the First Point of Enterprise Access?

The answer depends on your organization's priorities:

  • If SAP integration is key: Start with SAP Fiori Launchpad or SAP Work Zone, depending on whether you need transactional access or a collaborative digital workplace.
  • If analytics is the focus: Use SAP Analytics Cloud for SAP data and Power BI or Tableau for non-SAP data.
  • If collaboration and integration are critical: SAP Work Zone is the clear winner, providing a unified interface for SAP and non-SAP tools.

Visualizing the Decision: A Comparison Chart & Decision Tree

To make this easier, here‚Äôs a quick comparison chart:

Feature

SAP Fiori Launchpad

SAP Analytics Cloud

SAP Work Zone

Power BI/Tableau

SAP Integration

Excellent

Excellent

Excellent

Limited

Non-SAP Integration

None

Limited

Excellent

Excellent

Analytics Capabilities

Basic

Advanced

Basic

Advanced

Collaboration Features

None

Moderate

Advanced

Limited

Best For

SAP Transactions

SAP Analytics

Unified Workplace

Non-SAP Analytics

 

                                                                               Figure: Decision Tree among the available Tools

Final Thoughts

In today's complex analytics environment, there is no single solution that fits every organization. Success lies in aligning technology choices with business objectives, data strategy, and user needs. The most forward-thinking enterprises design flexible analytics ecosystems, balancing governance, agility, and usability to ensure analytics becomes an enabler, not a barrier.

Based on experience across multiple SAP programs, hybrid architectures often offer the strongest foundation. SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) provides deep integration and governance for SAP data, while platforms like Power BI or Tableau enhance visualization and flexibility for non-SAP data sources. Combined with centralized data hubs like Snowflake or SAP Datasphere or SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC), this model ensures consistency, scalability, and end-to-end insight.

As SAP continues to innovate, solutions such as SAP Work Zone and the SAC Catalog are transforming how users access, share, and collaborate on analytics content. They bridge the gap between SAP and non-SAP systems, creating a truly unified workspace for both business and IT teams.

Ultimately, the goal is not to choose a single tool but to build an integrated analytics ecosystem, one that empowers users at every level to make data driven decisions confidently. Whether an organization adopts a purely SAP centric approach or a hybrid model, the future of analytics lies in seamless connectivity, collaboration and intelligent decision making.

entry.title: Local Currency change impact on Group reporting
entry.content:
We are planning to change the functional currency from local currency to Group currency USD for some of the consolidation units in the ledger Company code settings for local reporting decided by the management.

We need to understand its implication on the Group reporting consolidation unit currency settings which is same as functional currency and the data is transferred from Universal Journal.

Since the data transferred from universal journal is so far in GBP and the data in group reporting is already updated as GBP if we change the currency to USD in GR CU, we would like to understand how the transaction data in group reporting presently in local currency GBP will be converted to USD and how the balances LC is carried forward.


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: Local Currency change impact on Group reporting
entry.content:
Based on help  https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/90c07e91c7a64f328be3fd6b48955b13/a8f3c709a7f642398f1dd15de35b5320.html

You can only change the local currency as of the first period of the year. When you change the local currency of a consolidation unit, the system translates the old local currency values into the new local currency during the balance carryforward. Because of this, you must assign a currency translation method to the consolidation unit.

However, be aware that changing the local currency of a consolidation unit can lead to inconsistencies in cases where data already exists for a consolidation unit that uses the local currency that‚Äôs to be changed.

Local currency change can be done only at the beginning of the year before balance carryforward. During the year you cannot change local currency. This is system limitation.

 

Others community blogs: 

https://community.sap.com/t5/supply-chain-management-q-a/ucd1032-change-in-the-local-currency-on-consolidation-unit/qaq-p/4936664

entry.title: Re: How to Track Offsetting Accounts Through Interim Acco...
entry.content:
Hi byd,

 
Your requirement to trace offsetting accounts through interim accounts (AP ‚Üí GR/IR ‚Üí Inventory) is a common challenge in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. The standard FI documents only display direct offsetting account relationships, making it difficult to trace back through clearing accounts to the original postings.

Standard Fiori Apps for Document Traceability

Display Line Items in General Ledger App This app can show offsetting account information when configured properly. In the Settings, enable the 'Offsetting Account' column to make it visible [1]. However, this still shows only the direct offsetting relationship (AP to GR/IR), not the complete chain.

Clear GR/IR Clearing Account App (MR11) This app helps manage GR/IR clearing account balances and can show the relationship between goods receipts and invoice receipts [2]. It provides visibility into:

  • Quantity differences between GR and IR
  • Outstanding balances on clearing accounts
  • Purchase order history with GR/IR assignments

Display Purchase Order Advanced App (ME23N) Navigate to Purchase Order History and select "Change View" ‚Üí "GR/IR Assgt" to see the relationship between goods receipt quantities and invoice receipt quantities [2].

Document Flow and Linking Capabilities

Three-Way Matching Reports For comprehensive document tracking, consider using:

  • My Purchasing Documents items app for connected documents with various filter criteria
  • Monitor Purchasing Documents by Material app showing PO, pending quantities, and values [3]

Custom CDS View Approach You can create custom reports joining relevant CDS views :

  • I_PurchaseOrderAPI01 for Purchase Orders
  • I_MaterialDocumentItem for GR material documents
  • I_SupplierInvoiceAPI01 for invoices
  • I_JournalEntry for accounting documents

Recommended Solution Approach

Option 1: Enhanced Standard Reporting

  1. Use the Reconcile GR/IR Accounts app to identify clearing account relationships
  2. Combine with Display Line Items in General Ledger for offsetting account visibility
  3. Cross-reference with purchase order history for complete traceability

Option 2: Custom Query Development Since Public Edition has limitations on direct customization, consider:

  1. BTP integration with custom analytics
  2. SAC queries connecting the relevant CDS views
  3. API-based solutions for data extraction and analysis

Option 3: Process Enhancement

  1. Implement systematic document referencing in posting descriptions
  2. Use additional reference fields to maintain traceability links
  3. Create periodic reconciliation procedures

Technical Implementation Notes

The offsetting account derivation logic follows SAP Note 39955, which displays "the offsetting account with the highest amount" when multiple accounts are involved [4]. This explains why you see GR/IR as the offsetting account rather than the original inventory account.

Best Practices

  1. Automatic Clearing Jobs: Use "Automatic Clearing" or "GR/IR Automatic Clearing" jobs in the "Schedule General Ledger Jobs" app to maintain clean clearing accounts [2]
  2. Document Flow Maintenance: Ensure proper document referencing throughout the procurement process
  3. Regular Monitoring: Implement periodic reviews using the available GR/IR monitoring apps

While there isn't a single standard report that provides the complete multi-level offsetting account flow you're seeking, combining the available Fiori apps with custom CDS view queries offers the most practical solution for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.

Would you like me to elaborate on any specific implementation approach or provide more details about configuring the available standard apps for your traceability requirements?


If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudo. This motivates me to serve you better

Br.Bob

entry.title: Using Communication Targets for Outbound RFC Communication in ABAP
entry.content:
For those of you, who want to keep unwanted (you could even say badly dressed) destinations out of their HTTP(S) connections, check out this blog post:
Receiver Validation HTTP - Enhance Your Security by Controlling Destination Usage

In the world of SAP systems, remote-enabled function modules (RFMs) are essential for connecting different systems and running functions remotely.  
In this article, you will be guided through the process of calling an RFM using communication targets. This ensures smooth integration between your SAP system and remote systems. There is even a song about this phenomenon called "Smooth Integrator" . You see what we did there? 

Why should you use communication targets? 
Well, imagine throwing a party and accidentally inviting your ex, your accountant, and that one neighbor who always complains about your music. Nobody wantsunwanted guests crashing their (SAP system) party!
That's what happens when you don't have control over which applications can use which RFC destinations. It's a security and maintainability nightmare.  
 
You might wonder how exactly communication target get to be the "life of the party".
Communication targets and application destinations provide a strong layer that simplifies complex processes. They define how your SAP system connects with external systems. For that we need to use specific configurations known as appplication destinations.  

What is an application destination, you ask?  
Imagine it as the ultimate party planner for your data! 

It's the one responsible for making sure your data arrives at the right place, with the right credentials, and doesn't end up going to the wrong party. You know, like that one time you got invited  to a LAN-Party, but  showed up at a wild rave instead. Oops! 

Let's dive into the technical details.  

When you create a communication target, you need to carefully choose which of the following settings suit you best: 

  • Enforce SAP GUI Support - it ensures application destinations allow GUIs and disallow Websocket RFC.  
  • Enforce Fast Serialization - mandates the use of Fast Serializer for application destinations, preventing issues by disallowing other serializers if the scenario was developed with Fast Serializer.  
  • Default Compression Mode - allows predefined settings for higher compression in WAN scenarios or fast compression in LAN scenarios. 

When using communication targets, you can create an application destination in the transaction APPLDEST.  This process ensures you communicate only with the intended recipients.  
You select your communication target and create a new application destination with a right-click: 

 

 

Then you just need to name it, enter the client and select CPIC for the RFC Type. 

Alright, now you have an application destination. You still need to enter some important details like the host name (it can be retrieved from transaction SM51), instance and which authentication method you want to use. 
Application destinations are crucial component for managing external connections efficiently and securely. And now you have one too. Good for you!
 
If you use Cloud capabilities,  communication targets are now available as well!
Instead of using the traditional APPLDEST transaction, the cloud environment introduces some differences regarding the application destination: 

  • In the cloud, you start by creating a communication scenario for outbound RFC, which defines the interaction between your SAP system and external systems.
  • A corresponding runtime configuration, including a communication arrangement and communication system, must exist for your scenario.
  • When a communication arrangement is saved, the system automatically creates an application destination.  

But wait, there's more!  
 
Communication targets can generally have either multiple or exactly one assigned application destination. If you're calling an RFC service via communication targets in your ABAP code, you use the CALL FUNCTION (‚Ä¶) IN REMOTE SESSION method, it is essential for running the function remotely. It is basically like sending an RSVP to your guest, ensuring they got the invite (you get a response much faster though). 
 
When a communication target has exactly one assigned application destination, the process is straightforward. In cases where a communication target has several assigned application destinations, a few additional steps are required.  
When you have several assigned application destinations, one must pass the name of the relevant application destination to the parameter application_destination when creating the communication target instance. This ensures that the correct destination is used during the remote session. Check out how easy it is:  

 

 

In this example we called the function RFC_SYSTEM_INFO and we wanted to find out the maximal resources. 45 is the result. 
That¬¥s a Bingo!

By following alle these steps, you can call RFMs using communication targets, improving the connectivity and functionality of your SAP system.  

Just remember, the key is in the configuration.  It should fit your specific needs, like making sure your party playlist has the right mix of songs to keep everyone dancing, and not just that one weird guy.  We all know that one guy who just loooves to play the DJ, please don¬¥t let him. 

To summarize, communication targets and application destinations let you: 

  • Control which applications can crash which parties (application destinations). 
  • Restrict access to only those who need it. 
  • Avoid runtime errors and security mishaps. 

 

In case you are not a party animal, check out the step by step guide:  
Calling a RFM via Communication Targets

entry.title: SAP Community Hobbies Serries: Most weekends, I jump out of airplanes with my friends
entry.content:
I began skydiving while I was still in high school.  I trained with several of my school friends, and I made my first jumps just after my eighteenth birthday.  I stayed active in the sport through college but eventually gave it up to start a career and, later, a family.

A return after four decades

When folks from that same high school class began planning a 40th anniversary reunion, a few of us who had been part of that original group decided to celebrate in a special way: by skydiving together again.

It was both nostalgic and eye-opening.

Our first jumps had been made with heavy military gear, round parachutes, and G.I. combat boots. What we came back to was an entirely different experience‚Äîrefined equipment, greater emphasis on safety, and the atmosphere of an athletic sport.

In those intervening decades, tandem jumping had become commonplace. Instead of days of training before a first solo jump, beginners can now make a safe, mentored jump strapped to an instructor after just a few hours of preparation. That innovation has made skydiving accessible to millions of people who otherwise might never have tried it.  And the sport has exploded: millions of people now make their first tandem jump in the US each year.

Me, stepping out of a jump plane at 13,500 feet. (Photo: Michael Houston)

For me and my friends, that reunion jump lit a spark. We remembered how much we loved this sport.

That was five years ago.  I have been active in the sport ever since.

Skydiving today spans many disciplines: wingsuits that let people glide like a bird, precision accuracy competitions where landing within millimeters of a target is the goal, or ‚Äúmovement‚Äù dives where jumpers press their bodies against the wind to cover distances across the ground.

My passion is Formation Skydiving - jumping in groups to build patterns in the sky. Sometimes these formations involve dozens or even hundreds of people, sometimes requiring multiple aircraft flying in formation and ‚Äì always - deep levels of focus and discipline for the jumpers to succeed.

A formation skydive that‚Äôs going well - over Southern California ‚Äì me, on the right leg of the gent in yellow.
(Photo: Xian Cam Xtreme Media)

Skydivers come from all sorts of professions.  My skydiving friends are salespeople, accountants, nurses, E.R. doctors, military and police officers. And computer folks - a surprising percentage are computing professionals.  And why is that an indoor and desk bound job also attracts so many of the same people to jump out of planes?  I can offer a guess: when I am dialed into a programming task, the daily distractions of the world disappear.  Time goes away, too.  Psychologists characterize this as something called ‚ÄúFlow State‚Äù.  You are engaged and ‚Äúin the moment‚Äù.  Nothing else matters.  It's a feature of the job that I like. Despite the dramatically different setting, my experience when skydiving brings a similar frame of mind.  Flow State has its own documented rewards.  After a day of jumping, I often have the same upbeat feeling as when I have been on a long run outdoors.

There is a saying floating around the sport, ‚Äúskydiving isn‚Äôt for everyone, but everyone should try it once.‚Äù There is well developed training to prepare you for the safety essentials, but no number of words can prep you for the sights, sounds, and thrill of your first jump.  You just must experience it yourself and today it is more accessible than ever. 

Try it yourself. Come share the skies with me and my skydiving friends.

Next in this series:

Next up, Jan Rumig will be telling you about about long walks and hiking.

entry.title: How Machines Learn: The Science Behind Model Training
entry.content:
Understanding Model Training ‚Äî A Step-by-Step Explanation

One must have heard the buzzwords ‚ÄúModel Training‚Äù, ‚ÄúMachine Learning", "Model Learning‚Äù, or ‚ÄúAI Model‚Äù quite often ‚Äî whether in tech discussions, product demos, or data science talks.

However, when it comes to explaining what actually happens during this ‚Äútraining‚Äù process ‚Äî in plain English or even in technical terms ‚Äî most people are left guessing. Is the model memorizing data? Is it adjusting something inside? What exactly is it learning?

In this blog, let‚Äôs peel back the layers and understand what truly happens when a model is trained ‚Äî step by step. We‚Äôll start from a simple analogy and then gradually move into the math behind the learning process. The goal is to make the idea of ‚Äúmodel training‚Äù not just familiar, but intuitively clear.

Analogy: A Child Learning to Throw a Basketball

To understand the model learning process in a simple, non-technical way, imagine a child learning to throw a basketball into a hoop.

Initially, the child doesn‚Äôt know how much force to use. On the first try, the ball falls too short or goes too far. Depending on the outcome, the child adjusts slightly and tries again. After a few attempts, the child improves and starts hitting the target consistently.

That‚Äôs exactly how a machine learning model gets trained ‚Äî it starts with random guesses, measures how wrong it was, adjusts itself, and improves over many repetitions. It learns not because someone told it what‚Äôs right, but by learning from its own mistakes.

Before We Begin Few Important Notes:

Data as Numbers

To train any model ‚Äî whether for image classification, prediction, or generative AI ‚Äî data must be represented numerically (as integers, decimals, or vectors). In this blog, we‚Äôll skip the mathematical details of data conversion to numeric format. As part of this blog we will take an example of data which is already in numerical form. 

Loss Function

A loss function is like a report card for a machine learning model. It tells the model how well or how poorly it performed on the training data by comparing its predictions with the actual answers. In simple terms, the loss function calculates the difference between what the model's predicted and what it should have predicted. The bigger the difference, the higher the loss ‚Äî meaning the model is doing poorly.

The whole idea of model training is to minimize the loss ‚Äî that is, to reduce the gap between what the model predicted and what it should have predicted with every iteration.

Optimizer

An optimizer is the part of the training process that helps the model to learn from its mistakes. Once the loss function tells the model how wrong it was, the optimizer decides how to adjust the model‚Äôs internal parameters (like weights and biases) to reduce that error in the next round.

Think of it like the model‚Äôs coach or guide ‚Äî after every attempt, it reviews the model‚Äôs performance (using the loss value) and gives it small, calculated corrections to move it closer to the right answer. Technically, an optimizer updates the model‚Äôs parameters ensuring that with every step, the model‚Äôs predictions improve.

Popular optimizers include Gradient Descent, Adam, RMSProp, and SGD.

Optimization step & Learning rate

Optimization step

An optimization step is the actual moment when the model updates its internal parameters (like weights and biases) based on what it learned from the loss function. The optimization step applies the gradients calculated in previous steps to make the model slightly better than before.

You can think of it as the model taking one step forward in the right direction toward minimizing the loss.
Over many such steps (iterations or epochs), the model gradually ‚Äúlearns‚Äù the best parameter values.

Learning Rate

The learning rate, often denoted by the Greek letter Œ∑ (eta), controls how big each optimization step should be. It‚Äôs a small numerical value that determines how quickly or slowly the model updates its parameters.

  • If the learning rate is too high, the model might overshoot the optimal point and fail to converge.
  • If it‚Äôs too low, the model will learn very slowly and take a long time to reach good performance.

In simple terms ‚Äî
The learning rate is like the step size the model takes while learning.
A good learning rate ensures the model moves steadily toward lower loss without jumping past the goal.

Mathematically: 

wnew = wold ‚àí Œ∑ √ó (‚àÇL/‚àÇw)
 
Now let's dive into the actual model training part. 

Introduction ‚Äî What Happens When a Model Trains

When we call below code in python:

model.fit()

we are asking the model to learn patterns that map inputs to outputs. Behind this simple command lies a mathematical cycle of prediction, error measurement, and gradual improvement.

In essence: Model training is about minimizing mistakes ‚Äî by repeatedly predicting, comparing, and correcting.
 
To truly understand what ‚Äúlearning‚Äù means, let‚Äôs dive one level down in the layers with a simple example: linear regression, where a line is fit to the provided data points using gradient descent.

Step 1: Getting the Historical Data and Understanding the Business Ask

To begin any model training process, we need historical records which holds the input and output values required for model training.

Let‚Äôs consider the below data points as our historical records, where x is the input and y is the output for our model training. It means that whenever x happened, what was the value of y.

xy
12
24
36

Business problem: Build a model that predicts y for any given x, based on the historical data.

Step 2: Making Predictions (Forward Pass)

Making predictions in world of model training is also referred to as ‚ÄúForward Pass‚Äù, where both true input and the true outputs (i.e. historical record samples) are provided to the model for it to start learning.

Since we are considering a linear regression as our example, we use the simple model equation:

≈∑ = w¬∑x + b

We‚Äôll start with random model parameters: w = 0 and b = 0, predictions for all (x, y) pairs are:

For three training data points values i.e. in the pairing of (x,y) as per above mentioned historical records:

(1,2), (2,4), (3,6)
xy (Actual)≈∑ (Predicted)
120
240
360

The model predicts nothing correctly yet ‚Äî it hasn‚Äôt learned.

Let‚Äôs break down one prediction for better understanding.
For example let us consider the pair (x,y) --> (1,2), where x is the input to the model equation and y is the expected output.
We have our parameters w and b both having value as ‚Äú0‚Äù.
If we substitute values of w, x and b in above equation, since both w and b are ‚Äú0‚Äù, the result will be ‚Äú0‚Äù.
Same thing happens with other paired values of (x,y). Hence all the predicted values are ‚Äú0‚Äù.

Step 3: Measuring the Error (Loss Function)

We measure how wrong the predictions are using Mean Squared Error (MSE), which is given by:

L = (1/n) Œ£(y·µ¢ ‚àí ≈∑·µ¢)¬≤

Substituting the numbers:

L = (1/3)[(2‚àí0)¬≤ + (4‚àí0)¬≤ + (6‚àí0)¬≤] = 18.67
So, the loss = 18.67 ‚Äî quite high.

The model now knows how bad it is doing, but not how to improve. That‚Äôs where gradients come in.

Step 4: Learning from Mistakes (Gradient Computation)

To improve, the model must figure out how changing each parameter (w, b) affects the loss.
This is done using gradients ‚Äî the partial derivatives of the loss with respect to each parameter.

‚àÇL/‚àÇw = ‚àí(2/n) Œ£ x·µ¢(y·µ¢ ‚àí ≈∑·µ¢)
‚àÇL/‚àÇb = ‚àí(2/n) Œ£ (y·µ¢ ‚àí ≈∑·µ¢)

At our current statue (w=0, b=0):

‚àÇL/‚àÇw = - (2/3) √ó [(1)(2) + (2)(4) + (3)(6)] = - (2/3) √ó 28 = -18.67
‚àÇL/‚àÇb = - (2/3) √ó (2 + 4 + 6) = -8

This tells the model to increase w and b to reduce the loss.

Step 5: Updating the Model (Optimization Step)

Now comes the optimization step ‚Äî where we update parameters in the opposite direction of the gradient, scaled by the learning rate (Œ∑).

Lets take Œ∑ = 0.1.

We update parameters using the learning rate (Œ∑):

wnew = w ‚àí Œ∑(‚àÇL/‚àÇw)
bnew = b ‚àí Œ∑(‚àÇL/‚àÇb)
 
Plugging in the values:
w = 0 ‚àí 0.1(‚àí18.67) = 1.867
b = 0 ‚àí 0.1(‚àí8) = 0.8

After iteration 1: w = 1.867, b = 0.8

Training doesn‚Äôt stop after one update.
We repeat the process (forward pass ‚Üí loss ‚Üí gradient ‚Üí update) for several epochs, each time bringing the model closer to the true pattern.

Let‚Äôs perform one more iteration to see the progression.

Iteration 2

Forward Pass
≈∑ = 1.867x + 0.8
 
xy≈∑ (Predicted)
122.667
244.534
366.401

Loss after iteration 2:

L = (1/3)[(2‚àí2.667)¬≤ + (4‚àí4.534)¬≤ + (6‚àí6.401)¬≤] ‚âà 0.34

Loss dropped from 18.67 ‚Üí 0.34 in just one iteration!

Compute Gradients
‚àÇL/‚àÇw = - (2/3) √ó [(1)(2‚àí2.667) + (2)(4‚àí4.534) + (3)(6‚àí6.401)] = - (2/3) √ó [‚àí0.667 ‚àí 1.068 ‚àí 1.203] = 1.86
‚àÇL/‚àÇb = - (2/3) √ó [(2‚àí2.667) + (4‚àí4.534) + (6‚àí6.401)] = 1.73
Update Parameters
w = 1.867 ‚àí 0.1 √ó (1.86) = 1.681
b = 0.8 ‚àí 0.1 √ó (1.73) = 0.627
 
After iteration 2:
w=1.681, b = 0.627
 
Loss has dropped sharply ‚Äî the model is learning!
 
Loss Summary Table:
IterationswbLoss
11.8670.80018.67
21.6810.6270.34

If we finish the training process after two iterations, the model for the given data would be represented by the equation: ≈∑ = 1.681x + 0.627

Here, the values 1.681 and 0.627 are the learned parameters (weight and bias) that the model has adjusted during training to best fit the data.

The animation attached shows how the regression line gradually adjusts during training for 10 iterations. With each iteration, the model updates its weight (w) and bias (b) to better fit the data points ‚Äî moving closer to the true relationship between x and y.

Additional Note:
For ease of explanation, we considered an example with just one input variable (x).
However, in real-world scenarios, models usually work with multiple input features, represented as x‚ÇÅ, x‚ÇÇ, x‚ÇÉ, ‚Ä¶, where each represents a different attribute or factor influencing the prediction.

Intuitive Summary

Model training is guided trial and error mechanism. Each iteration:
  • The model guesses (forward pass).
  • It checks how wrong it was (loss).
  • It learns from the error (gradient).
  • It updates itself slightly (optimization).
  • It repeats until mistakes are minimal.

And that‚Äôs how a simple mathematical routine turns into a ‚Äúlearning‚Äù machine or what we proudly call today a ‚ÄúMachine Learning Model.‚Äù

entry.title: Implementing the Template Method Design Pattern
entry.content:
The Template Method pattern establishes a common framework for a process while letting derived classes implement their own versions of certain steps.

For example, generating reports in different formats (PDF, Excel, Text) might have differences in export or formatting logic, but the sequence of operations remains the same:

  1. Fetch data

  2. Prepare output

  3. Download or display the result

 

 

 

METHOD fetch_data. 
    DATA: ls_sales_data TYPE zug_sales, 
           lt_sales_data TYPE zug_t_sales. 
    SELECT SINGLE * 
  FROM vbak 
  INTO (ls_vbak) 
  WHERE vbeln = _vbeln. 
 
    " Fetch Items 
     SELECT * 
       FROM vbap 
       INTO TABLE (lt_vbap) 
       WHERE vbeln =   _vbeln. 
 
    "------------------------------------------------------------ 
     " Combine Header + Item into Final ITAB 
     "------------------------------------------------------------ 
     LOOP AT lt_vbap INTO DATA(ls_vbap). 
       CLEAR ls_sales_data. 
       ls_sales_data-vbeln = ls_vbak-vbeln. 
       ls_sales_data-kunnr = ls_vbak-kunnr. 
       ls_sales_data-vkorg = ls_vbak-vkorg. 
       ls_sales_data-vtweg = ls_vbak-vtweg. 
       ls_sales_data-spart = ls_vbak-spart. 
       ls_sales_data-auart = ls_vbak-auart. 
       ls_sales_data-posnr = ls_vbap-posnr. 
       ls_sales_data-matnr = ls_vbap-matnr. 
      ls_sales_data-vrkme = ls_vbap-vrkme. 
 
      APPEND ls_sales_data TO lt_sales_data. 
     ENDLOOP. 
 
    gt_data 
 
     = lt_sales_data. 
   ENDMETHOD. 

  DATA: lt_output TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF string, 
         lv_filename TYPE string, 
         lv_line   TYPE string. 
 
  " Header line 
   lv_line = |VBELN;KUNNR;VKORG;VTWEG;SPART;AUART;POSNR;MATNR;VRKME|. 
   APPEND lv_line TO lt_output. 
 
  " Data lines 
   LOOP AT gt_data INTO data(ls_sales_data). 
     lv_line = |{ ls_sales_data-vbeln };{ ls_sales_data-kunnr };{ ls_sales_data-vkorg };{ ls_sales_data-vtweg };{ ls_sales_data-spart };{ ls_sales_data-auart };{ ls_sales_data-posnr };{ ls_sales_data-matnr };{ ls_sales_data-vrkme }|. 
     APPEND lv_line TO lt_output. 
   ENDLOOP. 
 
  "------------------------------------------------------------ 
   " Download to file 
   "------------------------------------------------------------ 
lv_filename  = 'C:\Users\user\Downloads\output1.txt'. 
 
  cl_gui_frontend_services=>gui_download( 
     EXPORTING 
       filename     = lv_filename 
       filetype     = 'ASC' 
     CHANGING 
       data_tab     = lt_output 
     EXCEPTIONS 
       OTHERS       = 1 
   ). 
 
  IF sy-subrc <> 0. 
     MESSAGE 'Error during file download' TYPE 'E'. 
   ENDIF.

 

 

 

METHOD fetch_data. 
 
    DATA: ls_sales_data TYPE zug_sales, 
           lt_sales_data TYPE zug_t_sales. 
    SELECT SINGLE * 
  FROM vbak 
  INTO (ls_vbak) 
  WHERE vbeln = _vbeln. 
 
    " Fetch Items 
     SELECT * 
       FROM vbap 
       INTO TABLE (lt_vbap) 
       WHERE vbeln =   _vbeln. 
 
    "------------------------------------------------------------ 
     " Combine Header + Item into Final ITAB 
     "------------------------------------------------------------ 
     LOOP AT lt_vbap INTO DATA(ls_vbap). 
       CLEAR ls_sales_data. 
       ls_sales_data-vbeln = ls_vbak-vbeln. 
       ls_sales_data-kunnr = ls_vbak-kunnr. 
       ls_sales_data-vkorg = ls_vbak-vkorg. 
       ls_sales_data-vtweg = ls_vbak-vtweg. 
       ls_sales_data-spart = ls_vbak-spart. 
       ls_sales_data-auart = ls_vbak-auart. 
       ls_sales_data-posnr = ls_vbap-posnr. 
       ls_sales_data-matnr = ls_vbap-matnr. 
 
      ls_sales_data-vrkme = ls_vbap-vrkme. 
 
      APPEND ls_sales_data TO lt_sales_data. 
     ENDLOOP. 
 
    gt_data 
 
     = lt_sales_data. 
   ENDMETHOD. 
DATA(lo_pdf) = NEW cl_apoc_pdf_generator( ). 
     lo_pdf->create_pdf( 
       EXPORTING 
         input             = gt_data 
       RECEIVING 
         pdf_binary_output = DATA(rv_bin) 
     ). 
 
    DATA: lv_bin     TYPE xstring, 
       lt_bin_tab TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF x255, 
       lv_size    TYPE i, 
       lv_filename TYPE string. 
 
lv_bin = rv_bin.  " Your PDF xstring 
 
" Convert XSTRING to BINARY TABLE 
CALL FUNCTION 'SCMS_XSTRING_TO_BINARY' 
   EXPORTING 
     buffer        = lv_bin 
   IMPORTING 
     output_length = lv_size 
   TABLES 
     binary_tab    = lt_bin_tab. 
 
" Set filename (local path) 
lv_filename = 'C:\Users\user\Downloads\output.pdf'. 
 
" Download to frontend 
cl_gui_frontend_services=>gui_download( 
   EXPORTING 
     bin_filesize = lv_size 
     filename     = lv_filename 
     filetype     = 'BIN' 
   CHANGING 
     data_tab     = lt_bin_tab 
   EXCEPTIONS 
     OTHERS       = 1 
). 
   endmethod.

 

 

 

 

DATA: ls_sales_data TYPE zug_sales, 
           lt_sales_data TYPE zug_t_sales. 
 
    SELECT SINGLE * 
  FROM vbak 
  INTO (ls_vbak) 
  WHERE vbeln = _vbeln. 
 
    " Fetch Items 
     SELECT * 
       FROM vbap 
       INTO TABLE (lt_vbap) 
       WHERE vbeln =   _vbeln. 
 
 
 
 
    "------------------------------------------------------------ 
     " Combine Header + Item into Final ITAB 
     "------------------------------------------------------------ 
     LOOP AT lt_vbap INTO DATA(ls_vbap). 
       CLEAR ls_sales_data. 
       ls_sales_data-vbeln = ls_vbak-vbeln. 
       ls_sales_data-kunnr = ls_vbak-kunnr. 
       ls_sales_data-vkorg = ls_vbak-vkorg. 
       ls_sales_data-vtweg = ls_vbak-vtweg. 
       ls_sales_data-spart = ls_vbak-spart. 
       ls_sales_data-auart = ls_vbak-auart. 
       ls_sales_data-posnr = ls_vbap-posnr. 
       ls_sales_data-matnr = ls_vbap-matnr. 
 
      ls_sales_data-vrkme = ls_vbap-vrkme. 
 
      APPEND ls_sales_data TO lt_sales_data. 
     ENDLOOP. 
 
    gt_data 
 
     = lt_sales_data. 
   endmethod. 

 

 

DATA: lo_salv_table TYPE REF TO cl_salv_table. 
DATA: rv_excel_bin TYPE xstring. " Holds the final XLSX binary data (XSTRING) 
 
" 1. Create ALV instance from the internal table 
TRY. 
     cl_salv_table=>factory( 
       IMPORTING 
         r_salv_table = lo_salv_table 
       CHANGING 
         t_table      = gt_data 
     ). 
 
" 2. Generate the XLSX binary data (XSTRING) 
     lo_salv_table->to_xml( 
       EXPORTING 
         xml_type  = if_salv_bs_xml=>c_type_xlsx  " Specify XLSX format 
       RECEIVING 
         xml       = rv_excel_bin 
     ). 
 
  CATCH cx_salv_msg. 
     " Handle ALV/XML generation error 
     MESSAGE 'Error during XLSX generation' TYPE 'E'. 
     RETURN. 
ENDTRY. 
 
* The rest of your download logic can remain similar, 
* but I'll use CL_BCS_CONVERT=>XSTRING_TO_SOLIX as it's often more standard 
* for converting to the format required by GUI_DOWNLOAD's BIN filetype. 
 
DATA: lv_bin      TYPE xstring, 
       lt_bin_tab  TYPE solix_tab,  " Use SOLIX_TAB for better compatibility 
       lv_size     TYPE i, 
       lv_filename TYPE string. 
 
" Move the generated Excel XSTRING 
lv_bin = rv_excel_bin. 
 
" Convert XSTRING to SOLIX (Binary Table for GUI_DOWNLOAD) 
* SCMS_XSTRING_TO_BINARY is still an option, but CL_BCS_CONVERT is often preferred. 
 
 
lt_bin_tab = cl_bcs_convert=>xstring_to_solix( iv_xstring = lv_bin ). 
 
" Get the size of the XSTRING for GUI_DOWNLOAD 
lv_size = xstrlen( lv_bin ). 
 
" Set filename (local path - user will be prompted) 
" IMPORTANT: Use a generic name unless you want a fixed path 
lv_filename = 'C:\Users\user\Downloads\output56.xlsx'. " Using 'C:\...' forces a specific path, better to use a simple name 
 
" 4. Download to frontend 
cl_gui_frontend_services=>gui_download( 
   EXPORTING 
     bin_filesize = lv_size 
     filename     = lv_filename 
     filetype     = 'BIN' " Must be 'BIN' for binary files (like XLSX) 
   CHANGING 
     data_tab     = lt_bin_tab 
   EXCEPTIONS 
     OTHERS       = 1 
). 
 
IF sy-subrc <> 0. 
   " Handle download error 
   MESSAGE 'Error during file download' TYPE 'E'. 
ENDIF.

 

For pdf. 

 

For text type 

 

 

Excel  

 

 

CONCLUSION

 The Template Method Pattern in ABAP provides a powerful way to design reusable and maintainable frameworks, especially when you have multiple processes that share a common structure but differ in certain implementation steps.

entry.title: This article explains the basic Idea and Architecture of SAP BODS
entry.content:
Understanding of SAP BODS?

SAP BODS stands for Business Objects Data Services.

It‚Äôs a tool used to extract data from different systems, transform it into useful information, and load it into a data warehouse.

In short, it helps combine and clean data so that organizations can make better decisions.

It supports data integration, data quality, data processing, and data profiling all in one platform.

Brief History of SAP BODS

  • In 2002, a company called BusinessObjects took over Acta‚Äôs tools and rebranded them as BusinessObjects Data Integration and BusinessObjects Data Quality.
  • In 2007, SAP acquired BusinessObjects, and the tools were renamed SAP BODI and SAP BODQ.
  • In 2008, SAP merged both products into one, which became SAP Business Objects Data Services (BODS) the tool we use today.

SAP BODS Architecture Overview

 

SAP BODS has several main components that work together:

 

                                                SAP BODS Architecture Diagram

 

  1. Repository

A repository is like a storage area that keeps all your project details such as metadata, source and target details, transformation rules, and objects created by users.

Each repository connects to one or more Job Servers which run the data jobs.

Repositories help share information with other systems and keep your data environment organized.

 

  1. Management Console

This is a web based tool used to monitor and manage jobs.

You can use it for:

  • Impact and Lineage Analysis
  • Administration and Auto Documentation
  • Operational Dashboards
  • Data Validation and Reporting

 

It gives you a complete overview of how your data flows and performs.

 

  1. Job Server

The Job Server runs your data movement and transformation processes.

It connects to multiple data sources, moves data in batch or real time, and handles extraction from ERP systems.

When you run a job from the Designer, the Job Server takes care of executing it.

 

  1. Data Services Designer

The Designer is where developers build and design jobs.

It has a graphical interface that allows you to drag and drop objects, define transformations, and control data flow.

It‚Äôs user friendly and helps you build workflows and manage repository metadata.

 

  1. Engines

Engines are the components that process your data once a job starts.

They handle extraction, transformation, and loading.

They are designed to perform tasks quickly using parallel processing and in memory transformations to improve speed and scalability.

 

  1. Access Server

This server handles real time messages.

It takes requests, routes them to the correct service, and returns the response within a set time.

This is useful when data needs to be updated instantly.

 

  1. Address Server

The Address Server helps in address validation and correction.

It must be running before executing any jobs that involve address cleansing or global address validation features.

Important Terms in SAP BODS

 

Datastore

A Datastore connects BODS to a data source, such as a database.

It lets you import metadata and provides the link between BODS and your backend system.

 

CMC (Central Management Console)

This is a web based admin tool where you can register repositories, manage users, and perform other administrative activities.

 

Data Integrator Web Administrator (DI Web Admin)

It helps manage repositories and services like job servers, meta repositories, and web services.

This tool keeps everything connected and maintained.

Advantages of SAP BODS

  • It provides high quality data profiling and supports data cleansing and transformation easily.
  • The user interface is simple and allows drag and drop functionality.
  • It‚Äôs quick to learn for beginners and efficient for developers.
  • You can build both batch and real time jobs.
  • It supports custom functions for complex data transformations.
  • It integrates well with SAP and non-SAP systems.

Disadvantages of SAP BODS

  • It‚Äôs expensive, especially for small companies.
  • It needs powerful hardware and sometimes multiple servers.
  • It requires a skilled development team to implement and manage.

Summary

 

SAP BODS is one of the most powerful tools for data extraction, transformation, and loading (ETL).

It allows organizations to connect to different systems, clean the data, and make it useful for reporting and analysis.

While it may cost more to set up, it offers strong performance, scalability, and flexibility for enterprise level data management.

                                                                                                                                                        Published by

                                                                                                                                                         Nikhat Fatima

entry.title: SAP EA - Real World Asset Tokenization with Distributed Ledger Technology on the SAP BTP Kyma üöÄ
entry.content:
I is for Innovation....   EA is about... the goal of this blog is to get us thinking and talking about tokenization before the Business turn up demanding it...

I've always wished and dreamed that us SAP EA's would know our Business so well and at the same time have Road Maps for all of our Technology Standards and including Emerging Standards so that we would know what Technical Capabilities the Business requires before they even come to us with their Demand.

In reality, in my experience 9 times out 10 it's the Business who come to EA with demands for new technologies (innovations).

How do we bring in or do "Innovation" ? Ideally with Roadmaps and Emerging Technology Standards. 

SAP's next generation Customer CoE guides SAP Guides for Customer COE provide thought leadership on bringing in innovations, Customer Center of Expertise - Strategy, Governance and Organization

and continuous-improvement-and-innovation-with-a-ccoe.pdf

Customer Center of Expertise   

ccoe_continuous_success_en.pdf

In SAP's documentation, in the North Star Architecture, in the next generation SAP CCoE,  innovation responsibilities come in to a number of Roles

And combined with the Digital Innovation Manager Digital Innovation Manager | Digital Technology and Innovation Management| SAP Community

And that is what this blog is about, innovation, and innovation in the area of Tokenization and RWA Real World Asset Tokenization.

There is a silent digital revolution going on, where evidence, assets, transactions are being given a digital fingerprint, a hash on a Distributed Ledger and being tokenized.

What is Tokenization and who's doing it and where is it going ?

Let's start by looking at what's happening in the space:

[Disclaimer - we cannot post links outside of the Community and if you want to read these articles then just go on your favourite search engine and find them]

Pairpoint - Vodafone Sumitomo JV

 

World Economic Forum

 

Fortune - Asia's quiet tokenization revolution

 

CNBC

 

Oracle

from the same article, this is how Oracle sees it:

 

If they all see Tokenization that way then maybe the EA innovation leads in our Organisations should be having a look at Tokenization too.

This older SAP article considered common use cases NFT (Non-Fungible-Tokens) | Digital Technology and Innovation Management | SAP Community

SAP has dipped their toes into the water with the SAP Green Ledger What Is SAP Green Ledger? | SAP Help Portal , in my opinion the scope is too narrow, Green Ledger: Where Carbon and Financial Accounting Unite   SAP Green Ledger and an ERP-centric approach to reinvent carbon accounting   and Carbon Accounting is the tip of the iceberg.

Learning.sap.com has some excellent resources including videos Blockchain  and this incredible Blockchain course What Can Blockchain Do for You .

Have a think about how Tokenization and Distributed Ledger Technology capabilities fit towards your Business, your Business Processes, your Business Partners.

Have a think about drawing the Blockchain Capability Map,  positioning Enterprise Blockchain as an Emerging Technology Standard, and then when the Business come with the Demand... let the use-case / Demand find the Blockchain, and if you want to have a play with Enterprise Blockchain on the BTP Kyma, even the BTP Trial Edition Kyma then just follow this blog and reach out if there are any questions.

And that's the purpose of this blog, to get Tokenization onto our EA radars.

What do you think, put your thoughts in the comments.

Ultimately this is all "Why I love SAP and Blockchain Databases and why you should too üöÄ".

Andy Silvey.

Independent SAP Technical Architect and SAP Basis SME [you might also find my SAP S/4HANA RISE & BTP Toolbox interesting:  üß∞üë∑‚Äç The SAP S/4HANA RISE & SAP BTP - Toolbox üë∑‚Äçüß∞] and CEO of atkrypto (.) io

Author Bio:

Andy Silvey is a 26 years SAP Technology veteran [26 years SAP Basis and  including 12 years SAP Tech Arch including Tech, Integration, Security, Data from 3.1H to S/4HANA PCE on RISE and the BTP and everything in between, and former SCN Moderator and Mentor alumni].

Andy is also co-Founder of atkrypto inc, an startup whose ambition is to make Blockchain easy for Enterprise.

atkrypto (.) io's flagship product is the atkrypto Enterprise Blockchain Platform for SAP,  and atkrypto (.) io is a SAP Partner Edge Open EcoSystem Partner. 

The atkrypto Enterprise Blockchain Platform for SAP has been designed by SAP Independent Experts for the needs of SAP Customers and to be deployed on the SAP BTP Kyma Runtime Service and leverage native integration to SAP Products.

atkrypto Enterprise Blockchain Platform for SAP has a number of unique qualities, including being the only Blockchain software in the world which has a DataCenter version and a light mobile version which can run on Edge/IoT/Mobile devices and enables data to be written to the Blockchain at the Edge where that same Blockchain is running on a Server in the DataCenter, protecting the integrity and originality of data from the Edge to Insights. Taking Blockchain to the Data at the Edge instead of taking the Data to the Blockchain.
